betsy.grammar

Class WordTree<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • betsy.grammar.WordTree<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of object used to tag each tree or leaf

    public class WordTree<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    A WordTree is used to group and arrange strings in a tree structure. There are two types of WordTree: a leaf has a single String -- the "word", and a tree has a list of other WordTrees -- its children. Both have an object -- the "type" -- used to identify and describe them. WordTree is a generic class so this object could potentially be anything. For Betsy, it is usually a Tag or a StructureTag. The WordTree's children can change, but everything else is immutable.
    Author:
    jacob

    • Method Detail

      • getType

        public T getType()
        Get the identifying "type" object of the tree
        Returns:
        the tree's type, of type T

      • isLeaf

        public boolean isLeaf()
        Check if the tree is a leaf. Leaves have a word and no children; trees may have children but do not have a word.
        Returns:
        true if the tree is a leaf

      • getWord

        public java.lang.String getWord()
        Get the WordTree's word, if it is a leaf.
        Returns:
        if the WordTree is a leaf, returns the leaf's word. If it is a tree, returns null.

      • getChildren

        public java.util.List<WordTree<T>> getChildren()
        Get the WordTree's children, if it is a tree
        Returns:
        an unmodifiable list. If the WordTree is a tree, the list will have its children; otherwise it will be empty.

      • getAllLeaves

        public java.util.List<WordTree<T>> getAllLeaves()
        Collapses all of the leaves in this tree, its children, their children, etc. using a depth-first search. The leaves are put together in order, in a list.
        Returns:
        a list of WordTree's, all of which are leaves. If this WordTree is a leaf, the list will have one item -- this tree. If it is a tree, it will call getAllLeaves() for each of its children and collect their responses, in order, in a list.

      • numChildren

        public int numChildren()
        Get the number of children this WordTree has
        Returns:
        the number of children returned by getChildren(). If this is a leaf, returns 0.

      • getChild

        public WordTree<T> getChild(int i)
        Get the child at the specific index.
        Parameters:
        i - the index of the child. Must be between 0 (inclusive) and numChildren() (exclusive)
        Returns:
        the child WordTree at that index

      • hasType

        public boolean hasType(T type)
        Check if one of the tree's direct children has the specified type.
        Parameters:
        type - the type to search for
        Returns:
        true if this WordTree has a direct child with this type. False if this is a leaf.

      • getType

        public WordTree<T> getType(T type)
        Get the first direct child of this tree with the specified type.
        Parameters:
        type - the type to search for
        Returns:
        the first one of this tree's direct children with that type. Null if none are found, or if this is a leaf.

      • getTypeIndex

        public int getTypeIndex(T type)
        Get the index of the first direct child of this tree with the specified type.
        Parameters:
        type - the type to search for
        Returns:
        the index of the first one of this tree's direct children with that type. -1 if none are found, or if this is a leaf.

      • getAllType

        public java.util.List<WordTree<T>> getAllType(T type)
        Get all direct children of this tree with the specified type.
        Parameters:
        type - the type to search for
        Returns:
        a list of each of this tree's direct children with that type. Return an empty list if none are found, or if this is a leaf.

      • hasLeaf

        public boolean hasLeaf(T type,
                       java.lang.String word)
        Check if one of the tree's direct children 1) is a leaf, 2) has the specified type, and 3) has the exact value of the specified word.
        Parameters:
        type - the type to search for
        word - the word to search for
        Returns:
        true if this WordTree has a direct child meeting these criteria. False if this is a leaf.

      • getLeaf

        public WordTree<T> getLeaf(T type,
                           java.lang.String word)
        Find the first direct child of this tree meeting the criteria described in hasLeaf().
        Parameters:
        type - the type to search for
        word - the word to search for
        Returns:
        the first of this tree's children meeting the criteria. Null if none are found or if this is a leaf.

      • getLeafIndex

        public int getLeafIndex(T type,
                        java.lang.String word)
        Find the index of the first direct child of this tree meeting the criteria described in hasLeaf().
        Parameters:
        type - the type to search for
        word - the word to search for
        Returns:
        the index of the first of this tree's children meeting the criteria. -1 if none are found or if this is a leaf.

      • getParent

        public WordTree<T> getParent()
        Get the "parent" of this WordTree - the tree that contains this tree as a child.
        Returns:
        this tree's parent, or null if none exists

      • addChild

        public WordTree<T> addChild(WordTree<T> tree)
        Add the given tree to this tree's children. Its parent will be automatically set. Behavior is undefined if this is a leaf.
        Parameters:
        tree - the new child
        Returns:
        the newly added child -- exactly the same as the input

      • removeChild

        public void removeChild(WordTree<T> tree)
        Remove the given tree from this tree's children. Its parent will be set to null. If the tree isn't a child of this tree, nothing happens. If this is a leaf, nothing happens.
        Parameters:
        tree - the child to remove

      • removeChild

        public void removeChild(int i)
        Remove the child at the specified index. Behavior is undefined if the index is out of range, or if this is a leaf.
        Parameters:
        i - the index of the child to remove

      • insertTree

        public WordTree<T> insertTree(WordTree<T> tree)
        Add the specified tree to this tree's parent, and move this tree into the specified tree.
        Parameters:
        tree - the tree to replace this one with
        Returns:
        the specified tree

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • wordListToString

        public java.lang.String wordListToString()
        Collapse all the leaves in this tree using the same method as getAllLeaves(). Then put spaces between each of the leaf's words, and combine them into a single string.
        Returns:
        the combined words of the leaves in the entire word tree

      • clone

        public WordTree<T> clone()
        Create a full copy of this tree, its children, their children, etc.
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a new tree with the same structure as this one, but new object instances.

      • exactMatch

        public boolean exactMatch(WordTree<T> tree2,
                          boolean ignoreExtraChildren)
        Check if this tree matches another. Children, or children's children, etc., can be in different orders, as long as they are the same values.
        Parameters:
        tree2 - the tree to compare this tree to
        ignoreExtraChildren - if true, any extra children in tree2 or its children that aren't in this tree will be ignored
        Returns:
        true if the trees match, as specified above
